title: 114_s1550
content: The Act titled "Program Management Improvement Accountability Act" establishes governmentwide standards for program and project management for executive agencies. The Deputy Director for Management is responsible for adopting standards, policies, and guidelines, overseeing their implementation, and chairing the Program Management Policy Council. The Deputy Director for Management oversees program and project management implementation, chairs the Program Management Policy Council, establishes standards for executive agencies, engages with the private sector for best practices, conducts portfolio reviews for high-risk programs, and coordinates agency program reviews annually. The Deputy Director for Management oversees program and project management implementation, chairs the Program Management Policy Council, establishes standards for executive agencies, conducts portfolio reviews for high-risk programs, and coordinates agency program reviews annually. Additionally, a 5-year strategic plan for program and project management is required. The Department of Defense is exempt from certain provisions if they are similar to existing policies. The Deputy Director for Management of the Office of Management and Budget will issue standards, policies, and guidelines within a year of the enactment of this Act. Regulations must be issued within 90 days after the standards are released, in consultation with the Program Management Policy Council. The Deputy Director for Management of the Office of Management and Budget, in consultation with the Program Management Policy Council, will issue regulations to implement the requirements of section 503(c) of title 31, United States Code. Additionally, each agency described in section 901(b) must designate a senior executive as a Program Management Improvement Officer. The Program Management Improvement Officer of each agency designated under section 901(b) must implement program management policies and develop strategies to enhance the role of program managers, including providing enhanced training opportunities. The Program Management Improvement Officer must provide training in relevant competencies for program and project managers in the private sector, focusing on cost containment for large projects and programs. The Program Management Improvement Officer aims to mentor current and future program managers, improve career paths, recruit highly qualified individuals, share best practices, and provide tools for data analysis. This does not apply to the Department of Defense if similar provisions are already in place. The Program Management Policy Council, established in the Office of Management and Budget, serves as the main interagency forum for enhancing agency practices in program and project management. The Program Management Policy Council, known as the 'Council,' is the primary interagency forum for improving agency practices in program and project management. It advises the Deputy Director for Management of the Office of Management and Budget, reviews high-risk programs, and discusses workforce development and continuous improvement in management policies. The Program Management Policy Council advises on career development, workforce needs, policy improvement, and program management challenges. It also reviews government-wide standards for program management transparency and OMB website information. Membership includes five members from the Office of Management and Budget. The Program Management Policy Council advises on career development, workforce needs, policy improvement, and program management challenges. It includes five members from the Office of Management and Budget, such as the Deputy Director for Management, Administrator of the Office of Electronic Government, Administrator of Federal Procurement Policy, Controller of the Office of Federal Financial Management, and Director of the Office of Performance and Personnel Management. The Program Management Policy Council includes the Deputy Director for Management of the Office of Management and Budget as the Chairperson, who presides over meetings, sets the agenda, directs the work, and establishes subgroups as needed. Other members include agency Program Management Improvement Officers and designated federal employees or Armed Forces members. The Program Management Policy Council, chaired by the Deputy Director for Management of the Office of Management and Budget, meets at least twice a year and may convene at the Chairperson's or majority members' call. Agency heads with Project Management Improvement Officers on the Council must provide administrative support as requested. A report is due within one year of the Act's enactment. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget, in consultation with Program Management Improvement Officers, must submit a report to Congress within one year of the Act's enactment. The report will contain the strategy developed under the specified section. Additionally, regulations regarding Program and Project Management Personnel Standards must be issued within 180 days of the standards, policies, and guidelines being issued under section 503(c) of title 31, United States Code. The Director of the Office of Personnel Management, in consultation with the Office of Management and Budget, must issue regulations within 180 days of the standards being issued under section 503(c) of title 31. These regulations will identify key skills needed for program and project managers, establish new job series or update existing ones, and create a new career path for managers within agencies. The Government Accountability Office will issue a report on the effectiveness of policies for improving Federal program and project management within 3 years of the enactment of this Act. This includes examining standards, policies, guidelines, and the 5-year strategic plan established under section 503(c) of title 31, as well as Program Management Improvement Officers designated under section 1126(a)(1) of title 31. The 5-year strategic plan, Program Management Improvement Officers, and Program Management Policy Council are established under title 31, United States Code.
